title: Parts of Speech - Nouns and Verbs
description: Discover the building blocks of language! Learn to identify and use nouns and verbs in sentences.
objective: In this lesson, you'll learn about two fundamental parts of speech: nouns and verbs. You'll practice identifying them in sentences and understand how they work together to create meaning.
concepts: Nouns are words that name people, places, things, or ideas
Verbs are action words that tell us what someone or something does
Every sentence needs at least one noun and one verb
Nouns can be concrete (you can touch them) or abstract (ideas/feelings)
Verbs can show action (run, jump) or state of being (is, are)

examples.problem: Find the noun: 'The dog barks loudly.'
examples.visual: The dog barks loudly.
examples.explanation: 'Dog' is a noun because it names an animal (a thing). It tells us who or what is doing the action.

examples.problem: Find the verb: 'Sarah runs every morning.'
examples.visual: Sarah runs every morning.
examples.explanation: 'Runs' is a verb because it shows action. It tells us what Sarah does every morning.

examples.problem: Identify both: 'The cat sleeps on the mat.'
examples.visual: The cat sleeps on the mat.
examples.explanation: 'Cat' and 'mat' are nouns (they name things), while 'sleeps' is a verb (it shows what the cat does).

quiz.question: Which word is a NOUN in this sentence: 'The teacher explains the lesson.'
quiz.explanation: 'Teacher' is a noun because it names a person. 'Lesson' is also a noun, but 'teacher' comes first in the options!
quiz.visual: The teacher explains the lesson.

quiz.question: Which word is a VERB in this sentence: 'Birds fly in the sky.'
quiz.explanation: 'Fly' is a verb because it shows action - it tells us what the birds do.
quiz.visual: Birds fly in the sky.

quiz.question: How many NOUNS are in this sentence: 'The student reads a book in the library.'
quiz.visual: The student reads a book in the library.

quiz.question: Which sentence has the correct noun and verb?
quiz.explanation: 'The rabbit jumps high' is correct. 'Rabbit' is the noun (names an animal) and 'jumps' is the verb (shows action).
quiz.visual: The rabbit jumps high.

quiz.question: What type of noun is 'happiness'?
quiz.explanation: 'Happiness' is an abstract noun - it names an idea or feeling that you can't touch or see, but you can feel it!
quiz.visual:
Abstract Noun: happiness
You can feel it, but you can't touch it!
